text:
Welcome to "Managing Through
Crisis," the weekly webcast

featuring faculty from Harvard
Business School sharing

insights for managers on how to
navigate through the COVID-19
crisis.

A 2002 article in
Harvard Business Review

titled "Crucibles of Leadership"
described experiences

that tested business
leaders, moments

that forced them to
question who they were
and what truly mattered to them.

Our guest today is
Professor Bill George.

He's the former chair
and CEO of Medtronic,

and someone who has thought,
taught, and written volumes

on leadership, including
crucible moments.

Bill, thank you so much
for joining me today.
Thank you, Brian.
It's great to be here.

I know you've been
out there very

active on the circuit talking
about how important leadership
is in a time like this.

And I think people are
going to really enjoy

hearing what you have to say
about the current situation.

Let me just ask you, in getting
us started down this path,

is this pandemic a crucible
moment, and what makes it so?

It certainly is,
and it certainly

is the greatest crisis of
my lifetime, far beyond 9/11

and what we experienced in
the financial world in 2008.

You'd probably have
to go all the way back

to World War II and
the Great Depression
to get anything close to it.

And so crisis is a real test
for every leader, Brian.

We find very different kinds
of leaders stepping up.

And it does get to
be a crucible for you

personally, because I think you
have to really search, who am I

and what is my essence here,
and what's my motivation,
and what's my calling?

And that brings you
right back to the core

of what you're all about,
your true north, if you will.

And it's calling out the
truly authentic leaders

who are stepping up and
making a huge difference,

whereas many others are
kind of fading away.

So I think it gets
right to that core.

And if you've suffered a
crucible early in your life

as I did as a teenager, a young
man in my 20s, or many people

have in mid-career when
they lost their job

or lost their
family or something,

you can go back to that
and think about that
and then go forward.

And I think people that have
that inner strength really
make the difference.

So in a time like
this, should leaders

be behaving differently,
or should they
be sort of steady as they go?

Maybe it differs depending
on the situation,

but I'm just wondering,
how does a leader know

if they're kind of
doing the right thing
in a time like this?

A crisis for leaders is
totally different than what
we teach about managing.

When you're managing
in steady times,

you delegate, you organize,
you analyze, you plan.
You have all kinds of time to--
we don't have any time.
We don't have data.
We don't have information.

We're flying blind
in many cases,
and yet people have to act.

They have to act to protect
the safety of their employees
and their customers.

People are operating
out of fear.

They have to make very
quick financial decisions.

Many companies are going to go
bankrupt as a result of this.

So when you're
managing in good times

like this in a nice growth
cycle, it's one thing.

But at a time like this, you
don't have time to do it.

So I say what's
really important,

though, is you have
to have great clarity
about your vision.
Think of yourself like a sailor.
You're going to that end point.
Never lose that endpoint.

Now, the storms
are buffeting you.

The winds are blowing
every which way.
Rain is coming down.

And so you have to have
a lot of resilience.

You're going to get
knocked down, knocked back.

But in addition to
that, you're going

to have to adapt quickly to
those changing conditions.

You can't just be
on a fixed plan.

You have to be willing
to use your intuition
and to adapt quickly.

And so, I think, then
you have to fall back

on your beliefs, your
principles, and your values
to know what to do.

And so an example is I talked
to Alex Gorsky, the CEO of J&J.

And he's got a small
business in vaccines.

They weren't even
a major player.

He's converting everything
trying to find a vaccine,

spending billions of dollars
to try to get there in a hurry

and trying to already ramp
up manufacturing facilities

to produce a billion
doses next winter.
So he's making that commitment.
That comes out of the J&J credo.

That comes out of beliefs that
we have to take care of people.

And so he's putting his
financials not totally aside,

but certainly, he's not
putting the emphasis on that.

So yeah, I think
the game changes
dramatically now for people.

I love hearing
about that example.

We actually spoke with
Rebecca Henderson last week

and we were talking
about her views

on reimagining capitalism at a
time like this in particular.

Do you see other
examples of leaders

out there who have
sort of found a way,

true to their core
values of their firm,

to add value in
a time like this?
Well, absolutely.

Omar Ishrak, at Medtronic,
my former company,
he's got a small business.

Accounts-- about 100th of
1 percent of his revenue's

based in Galway, Ireland
and produces ventilators,
and it came to an acquisition.

All of a sudden, this
becomes the major product,
the major shortfall.
So what's he do?
He gears up production.

He doubles and he'll
quadruple production,

calling in workers
from other facilities,
making sure they're safe.

But at the same time, he's
taken a smaller-end ventilator

and he's now open-sourced
it, so he's providing it

to General Motors, to Ford,
to Tata Industries in India,

to Foxconn operating in
Wisconsin so they can really
gear up production.

And he's called on Elon
Musk personally, Tesla,

to make a critical element,
a solenoid valve so they
can expand their production.
So it's really interesting.
He's got secure supply lines.

He's happy to have the
Defense Production Act.

It helps him secure
his supply line.

So yeah, he's an example
of doing just that.

What do you think
about the kinds

of leaders that are sort
of front and center today?
We've got leaders in government.
We've got our president.
We've got governors.

We've got mayors who are really
center-stage on this thing.

We've got leaders in
firms and organizations

who have ways that
they can contribute.

How do you view
those different kinds

of leadership and the roles
that those folks are playing,

and what are your thoughts on
how they can work together?

Well, they need
to work together,

but oftentimes,
there's not a plan

or it's too slow coming
from the [INAUDIBLE]..

A tremendous amount
of-- actually

very fast from the
Federal Reserve.

The stimulus efforts coming
out of Congress is very quick.

So they're putting a
lot of money out there,

but that's not addressing
a lot of the problem.

We have huge supply chain
problems with FEMA right now.

Mike Roman over at 3M,
FEMA took all of his masks.

And so an organization like
Mayo Clinic, the world's leading

medical center, they can't
even get masks right now.
I talked to the CEO.
We're fourth in line.

Gianrico Farrugia said, we have
to go stand behind the states,
behind FEMA.

We can't get direct
ship from 3M.
This is a huge problem for us.

And so this is a very
complex situation.

I think, in the absence
of this, governors

are stepping up
and taking action.

And you see governors
like Governor Newsom

out in California and
Governor Cuomo in New York

and Governor Baker
in Massachusetts,

Governor DeWine in Ohio really
stepping up and acting ahead

of the federal government
and putting things in place

and now deciding what's safe for
their people, closing schools.

And Larry Bacow at
Harvard was, I think,

the second school in
the nation to close.
He was way ahead of the game.
Thank goodness he did.

Other places, they held back
and they didn't move quickly,
so you've got to move fast.

Now, I think the business
leaders are doing a fantastic

job leading from
purpose and focusing

on what's really important,
the safety of their employees
there.

I talked to a group of 12 large
company CEOs this morning.

They are working really
hard to keep their employees
[AUDIO OUT] furloughed.

Some of them have to,
like Best Buy did.

But many others are holding
onto everything they
can to keep their employees.

Almost all the CEOs I know
are taking pay cuts, 40,

50 percent, 25
maybe in some cases.

And they're asking
salaried employees

to take pay cuts too to try
to keep their employee base.

But the longer this goes on,
the harder that will be to do.
We've got to be realistic.

They won't be able to
do that indefinitely

because they're going to
face a liquidity crunch.

Now, yes, you can
get loans out there,

but you better get them
quick because there's

going to be a huge liquidity
crunch coming for companies.

A lot of what we've talked
about is just the uncertainty
that exists out there.

Nobody has been
through this before.

It's truly a first
for the world.

We don't know where it's
going, and that puts leaders,

I think, in a
challenging position

because people want
to hear from them.
You want to hear from your CEO.

You want to hear from your
boss to give you some sense

for, when do we come
out of this thing?

What advice would
you give to leaders

as they grapple with this,
dealing with the unknown

but I know I've got
to say something.

I talked to the CEO of Cargill
this morning, David MacLennan.

He's come to a lot of
our programs at Harvard.

And he said, I'm out there all
the time with my employees.

I'm delivering regular
messages via video.

I sit down, record one
every Sunday night,

send it out Monday
morning, two minutes.

But basically, I've
got to be very blunt

and tell people
what's happening,

but I've got to give them hope
that we'll get through this.

We're going to pull
together at Cargill.

We're the world's
largest private company.

We're going to get through
this, but I've got to be blunt.
I've got to be honest.

I've got to define reality
for them and tell them,
here are the consequences.

So for instance, in his
business, the food service

business, restaurants
going down to 0, and yet

the consumer business
at grocery stores
is booming, up 90 percent.

So they've got to make fast
shifts in their factories

and packaging and
everything else,

and he's got to make sure
employees feel safe coming
to work all around the world.
He's got hundreds of factories.

So these are the challenges, but
I'm really proud of these CEOs.

They're stepping
up and following

their sense, their true north,
their purpose for their company

and making a difference and
putting employees first,

putting their customers first,
and knowing, in the end,

the shareholders and
investors will come out
better because they did it.

We had some great questions
come in from our audience,

the people who are
watching this series,

and I want to have you respond
to a couple of those questions.

And this is a good segue because
you just sort of touched on it.

What about leaders who are
on the front lines, people

who are working in the
health care industry?

So we've got doctors who have
been thrust into positions

that they weren't
before, or people

who are working in the
food service industry
or other essential services.

If you're leading an
organization like that,

how do you make your
employees feel safe?

How do you make them
feel inspired to come

to work every day despite the
tragic things that many of them
are witnessing?

I got an email from one of my
former students, Saquib Rahim,

an MBA at Harvard Business
School who tells--
he is an executive with Aetna.
He's also a doctor.

He's got an MD, MBA, and
he went on the front lines.

He's been in the COVID service
at NewYork-Presbyterian

Hospital for 33
consecutive days in Queens.
And he said it's so sad.

He sent out a picture,
the empty bed.

He said, every day,
one of my patients

dies, and I have to
go in and tell them.

Or the mother says,
please, can you

go in and tell my
husband goodbye
because I can't go see him?
She's sitting at home.

She can't go see her own
husband when he's dying.
He just said it's so sad.
How do you tell someone?

He said, a patient
asked me, could I die?
Yeah, you could.

So you try to give them
hope, but it's very--

health care workers are the
real heroes, people like Saquib.
They're amazing heroes.

We all want to
honor military vets.

Now we're going to really
honor the health care hero.
But let's go beyond that.

I think the front line workers
are the heroes, people working

in warehouse, people working in
delivery in an Amazon warehouse
or home-delivery groceries.

Everyone in New York is getting
home-delivery groceries.
How does it get there?

Somebody's got to
risk their life
to deliver to these people.

The people that are
working in factories

trying to produce
lifesaving products-- you
have to have that mask.
They're willing to do that.

So I think we're going to
revalue the first-line workers.

I think, sadly, for the
last two decades, Brian,
we devalued them.

We put our money into middle
managers and consultants.

I see far fewer middle
managers in the future.

I think everyone ought
to have a span of control
of 15 to 20 people minimum.

I think we'll lose
far fewer consultants.

It will depend on the
first-line workers.

And we're going
to pay them more.

Doug McMillon of Walmart,
he stepped up right away

and paid $550 million
more to his people.

That was way back
in early March.

And Brian Cornell out of
Target did the same thing,

$350 million to upgrade the
compensation of his employees.

And I think we'll see
a lot more of this,

and I'm really
excited about that.

I think we'll have
thinner organizations.

And the CEOs, even though
they're going to stay in place,

they've got to be
on the front lines.

One way, they've got to be
out there with their people.

Whether it's a Zoom
call like this one

or whether it's a video
or whether it's actually

physically going in there and
seeing how people are doing

in that hospital,
they have to do it

because people need to know
their leaders are with them.

So as a leader, you need
to be out front, up front
with your people.

You can't sit back and
let somebody else do it.

You've got to do it and
you've got to take the risk.

And it is a risk,
but there's a lot
of risks in this environment.
Yeah.

We had a viewer ask an
interesting question.

Who's a leader that
you look up to and why?
Well, I've mentioned a few.

There are a lot of
leaders I look up to.

Ken Frazier at Merck, I got him
to come on CNBC the other day.
He's CEO of Merck.

By the way, he's
grandson of a slave,

and Ken has done amazing
things with Merck.

And again, he has an
antibiotic business.
You don't think of this.

He said, people don't
die of coronavirus.
They die of pneumonia.
They get pneumonia.
He said, in my factory--

this is a month ago
or four weeks ago.

My factory, he said, I've only
got 300 out of 600 workers

there because they've
got to have daycare.
We've got to figure this out.
How do we get them help?

And so he's stepping up
and putting a lot of money

into the antibodies
because he said,

you know, way to make
money in this business-- we
make money in expensive drugs.
But he said, we've got to do it.

And so I admire
someone like him.

And I think I mentioned
Corie Barry from Best Buy.

She's doing everything
to preserve our employees

and totally transform
the business so they

can do totally online
business and pick-up

at the store and no-touch
pick-up and someone
to load it into your trunk.

You can get everything
you want because there's

been a huge surge right
now in home PCs and laptops
and printers and all kinds of--

people want to
have entertainment.
They want to be connected.

So I think people are having
to make those transformations.

So Corie's doing great, a new
CEO but doing a great job.

And I think we're seeing a
lot more people like that.
Mary Barra at General Motors--

the automobile business
is going to be down now.

It's probably going to
be down for some time.
She's making ventilators.

They don't know the
ventilator business,

but she's stepping
up to do that.
Yeah.

It sounds like one
of the themes that

comes from all these
examples you're giving

is that CEOs are not thinking
about the bottom line.

And I think that's a
really important thing

because, so often,
firms are looked

at critically because they focus
too much on the bottom line

and they don't focus enough
on customers and employees
and others.

But do you see a change,
sort of a turnabout that's

happening here that could impact
the way CEOs think about not

just today but tomorrow
and next year and beyond?
Yeah, I do.

I think they'll realize
that their business is
dependent on their customers.

And the CEOs--
there's going to be--

you know, we had
before COVID-19, BC,

and we have post-
or after-COVID-19.

Afterward, they're going to
have to restructure the business

models and they're going
to have to lead out.

They're going to
have to do what's
right for their customers.

And they have to move
quickly, and the employees

are going to have
to be very adaptive.

Those companies,
those leaders that

are focused on
customers and employees

are the ones where the
investors will really flourish.

I mentioned J&J
earlier, but there

are many examples where
companies have actually

really worked carefully
with customers in a place.

They will flourish
for investors,

but I think they have
to do those things first

and you have to
be very flexible.

You haven't got a lot
of time right now,

so you've got to think through,
what's the business going
to look like?

It's going to be dramatic
in how it's going to change.

It's not going to come
back the way we left it.

People are going to
eat at home more.

They're going to do much
more online shopping.

They're not going to
go to big mall stores.

You're not going to have
these malls, I don't think.

No one's going to
build a new mall.

And I think a lot
of things will--

I think transportation
will change dramatically.

I think more people will find
other ways to get to work,

and a lot of people are
walking around where I am.

But I think you'll have to have
a whole new business model.

And every CEO I've talked to
is thinking about that right

now and having teams form to
think through that new business
model.
We had a viewer ask us--

and you touched on this
a little bit earlier

when we talked about sort of
the thinning of the management
ranks--

do you have advice for
somebody who's not currently
in a leadership role?

Are there things
that they could be

doing during this
crisis that would

help them take advantage
of the opportunities that
might be there?

Yeah, step up and
lead right now.
You don't have to have a title.
Forget the title.

If I'm a CEO, I'm
going to look to see,

who are the informal
leaders that everyone
listens to, follows?

Who are the people that are
willing to step up and make

the changes and get
things done in a hurry?

Those are the people
that, post-COVID,
we're going to be honoring.
So yeah, I say step up.
You can lead.

You don't have to
wait for somebody
to tap you on the shoulder.
Go get it done.
Look for opportunities.
Get on the front lines.

Get out with people
where the action is
and make those changes now.

Make it safe for people to
come to your place of business

and people to work
in your factories.
Figure that out.

Be the person that's
taking the-- figure out

how the business model
is going to change.

I think those are the people
that are going to really come
out of this well.

So everyone, I'd like say
it to everyone on this call,
you can lead right now.

And please step up and
do it because we'll

find out who the real
leaders are in this crisis.

And those are the ones
that are going to come out

after the crisis, and
we'll be looking to them
for greater responsibility.

At least, if I were
in charge, we would.

I can't think of a better
note to end on, Bill.

Thank you so much for spending
some time with us tonight.

Thank you very
much for the time.

And I just want to
say, I think it's

a great opportunity for all
of us to make a difference,

and we're recreating our sense
of humanity and togetherness
even though we're separate.

And I think that's one
of the things that's

going to come out of this,
reevaluating our own lives

and put the emphasis on
things that really matter,

and that's the care of
the people we care about

and coming together in
a sense of community.

Thank you, Brian, for
creating this community.
Thanks a lot.
